> > Yes, it is possible.  In fact we've done XOR runs before where the
> > =
starting topology is completely disconnected (i.e., 0 connections)
> > and =
it is able to find a solution.
> >
> > - Philip
> 
> Thanks for your reply,=
 Phillip.
> 
> As a practical matter, is setting all connections to zero (i=
ncluding
> input connections) somthing that I set through the properties fi=
le or
> is it something I need to code?  Thanks again.

If, by input connec=
tions, you mean connections incoming to the input
layer,  those don't have =
weights, they serve only to pass the input
values to the input neurons.  Th=
e initial input values to the network
would be dependant on the fitness fun=
ction.

All genes, including connection genes, are set to random initial
va=
lues in the following call path:
com.anji.neat.Evolver() constructor 
  org=
.jgap.Genotype.randomInitialGenotype() 
    org.jgap.ChromosomeMaterial.ran=
domInitialChromosomeMaterial()
      org.jgap.Gene.setToRandomValue()

The =
4 best alternatives I see offhand for accomplishing what you want:

1) Chan=
ge the ConnectionGene.setToRandomValue() method to initialize
the weight to=
 0.  That would cause all newly added connections, not
just those of the in=
itial population, to start out with a 0 weight.
2) Change ChromosomeMateria=
l.randomInitialChromosomeMaterial() so that
it does not call Gene.setToRand=
omValue().  The weight in
ConnectionGene objects defaults to 0, and
NeuronG=
ene.setToRandomValue() doesn't do anything (although it will
when we make n=
eurons genes more complex, for example to have different
activation functio=
ns).
3) Have the Evolver constructor loop through all ConnectionGenes,
imme=
diately after the call to Genotype.randomInitialGenotype(), and
explicitly =
set the weights to 0.
4) The only way to do it without code changes would b=
e manually to
create an initial population of chromosomes.  You can hand-co=
de the
XML files (giving all the connections weights of 0) and save them in=

the db/chromosome directory, and reference them from a run.xml file in
the=
 db/run directory.  Then, when you start a run specify the run.xml
file wit=
h the "previous.run" property.  The initial population will be
seeded from =
those chromosomes.

I hope that helps!

- Philip
